name: The Ultimate The Incredibles Quiz |    Movies

questions.text: The film opens with some "documentary" footage and a sequence depicting a couple of our heroes as relatively young do-gooders.  Soon after these events, though, we learn that super-heroes are forced to "retire" and resume more mundane lives.  Once this sequence ends, how much time has passed when we next see Mr. Incredible?
questions.explanation:
15 years.

	A title card reads "15 years later".

questions.text: In what industry does Mr. Incredible work, in his civilian identity?
questions.explanation:
insurance.

	Bob Parr works as an insurance agent, albeit one who is more interested in helping the claimants than preserving company assets.

questions.text: Young Violet Parr has a crush on a boy she knows at school.  What is his first name?
questions.explanation:
Tony.

	Violet's brother Dash teases her mercilessly about Tony...but one has to wonder how Dash even knows Tony's name, since he and his sister attend different schools, and it doesn't seem like Violet shares many details about her personal life with her little brother.

Robert.

	At one point, when Dash's mother is angry with him, she calls him by his full name, Dashiell Robert Parr.

questions.text: Some "normal" people in this film seem to feel resentment toward (or fear of) the super-heroes they encounter.  What do the "normal" people usually call the heroes?
questions.explanation:
supers.

	Several times in the film, we hear the superhuman characters referred to, usually in a pejorative way, as "supers."

questions.text: At the beginning of the film, how long have Mr. Incredible and his family lived in the house they currently occupy?
questions.explanation:
3 years.

	Helen Parr calls her husband at work to tell him that she has finally unpacked the last box from their most recent move three years ago.  Apparently, the Parrs have had to move a number of times...whenever Bob Parr has let his powers be seen in public.

questions.text: What is the real first name of Syndrome, the villain of this film?
questions.explanation:
Buddy.

	Buddy, who idolized Mr. Incredible as a boy but was rebuffed by him, grows up to become Syndrome.

questions.text: Edna, the elite costume designer for the super-hero community, absolutely refuses to add masks to any of her designs.
questions.explanation:
False.

	Edna's fine with masks -- it's capes that she hates!

questions.text: Which of the following superhuman abilities is NOT possessed by any of the members of the Parr family?
questions.explanation:
flight.

	Elasti-Girl can turn her body into a parachute, but that's not flying.  Notice how helpless the Parrs are at the climax of the film, when Syndrome is flying away with Jack-Jack.

questions.text: Aside from the Parrs and Frozone, we get glimpses of a number of other super-heroes in the film.  Which is NOT one of them?
questions.explanation:
Blue Tiger.

	Gazer Beam is found dead at Syndrome's island.  Thunderhead is one of the deceased heroes mentioned by Edna.  Gamma Jack is one of the heroes whose files Bob Parr comes across in Syndrome's computer.  I made up "Blue Tiger".

questions.text: While flying in what he thinks is a government-owned, auto-piloted aircraft, Mr. Incredible is offered a second helping of something by the craft's apparently semi-intelligent computer.  What is it?
questions.explanation:
mimosa.

	Bob Parr is eating shrimp cocktail and drinking mimosa.  The computer asks if he would like more mimosa (which, by the way, is a drink made with champagne and orange juice), and he accepts a second glass.  (He's never offered a second helping of shrimp cocktail.)

questions.text: What is the real first name of Mirage, Syndrome's partner?
questions.explanation:
It's never revealed.

	Mirage, voiced by Elizabeth Pena, never tells anyone in the film her real name.

questions.text: When Mr. Incredible first decides to get back into shape for his revitalized super-hero career, his waist measures 50 inches.  After working out for some time, he's pleased with his new waistline.  What's the new measurement?
questions.explanation:
36 inches.

	We see these measurements clearly on the tape measure that Bob uses.

questions.text: What is the name of the villain who makes a dramatic appearance at the very end of this film?
questions.explanation:
The Underminer.

	A short, stout man who uses gigantic machinery to burrow up to street level from deep underground?  Sounds a lot like the Mole Man, whom the Fantastic Four (Marvel Comics' "first family") battled in the very first issue of their comic book...and, given the powers of The Incredibles, the Fantastic Four seem to have been a strong influence on writer/director Brad Bird all the way around!

questions.text: This is not the first time that the director of this film, Brad Bird, has directed a successful animated motion picture.  What else did he direct?
questions.explanation:
The Iron Giant.

	Bird directed the absolutely brilliant "The Iron Giant" (go check it out!), but made no contributions to any of the other films listed.
